title-group.subtitle: Antecedents and Effects of Delight Online

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Christopher Bartl is a doctoral candidate at EBS Business School in Oestrich-Winkel, Germany and has worked there as a research assistant at the Chair of Services Marketing and at the Center for Service Excellence. His research interests are customer delight, service excellence, and consumer behavior.

Matthias H. J. Gouthier (PhD, University of Eichstaett-Ingolstadt) is a professor of services marketing and director of the Center for Service Excellence, both at the EBS Business School in Oestrich-Winkel, Germany. He has published in International Business Review, Journal of Service Management, Managing Service Quality, and Marketing Theory, among others. His research interests are customer delight, service excellence, service-oriented human resource management, service productivity, and customer experience management.
Markus Lenker is an external doctoral candidate at EBS Business School in Oestrich-Winkel, Germany. His research interests are online marketing and customer delight.

author-notes.corresp: Matthias H. J. Gouthier, EBS Business School, Rheingaustr. 1, 65375 Oestrich-Winkel, Germany. Email: matthias.gouthier@ebs.edu

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: IT-Related Service: A Multidisciplinary Perspective
This special issue of JSR was organized under the Editorship of Katherine N. Lemon

abstract.p: The increasing importance of information technology as a means to access and communicate information has prompted firms to enhance their corporate websites to establish relationships with potential and current customers. Likewise, the value of satisfaction has decreased in favor of customer delight. To develop innovative and delighting websites, however, firms require a more detailed understanding of how they can optimize their websites’ user impact. In two empirical studies, this research shows that delight has a stronger impact on purchase intentions than website satisfaction does. This means that companies can benefit from positive repercussions after investing up front to enhance their website. This research also identifies individual website quality factors that firms can manipulate to create delightful consumer web experiences. By examining and distinguishing between their effects on delight and surprise, this research sheds light on how consumers perceive website quality factors. Overall, this research shows how firms can attain customer delight in an online environment and clarifies its effects on consumer behavior.

body.p: In an effort to counteract increasing national and international competition, service industries and corporations worldwide have aimed to achieve customer delight over mere satisfaction to secure their competitive position, establish long-term customer relationships, and ensure increased and persistent levels of loyalty and repurchase intentions (Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997; Schneider and Bowen 1999). While satisfying consumers largely involves meeting their expectations, consumers experience delight in response to unexpected and surprising service experiences (Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997), high levels of service quality, and innovative services (Arnold et al. 2005; Barnes, Ponder, and Dugar 2011; Menon and Dubé 1999). Therefore, delight reflects a consumers' intense, emotional response following unexpected and positive service performance that exceed the established average service level in an industry. In turn, consumers experiencing delight exhibit higher levels of behavioral outcomes, such as loyalty and purchase intentions.

Technological advances and user interest in information technology have led consumers to embrace the Internet as a simple, accessible information channel. In turn, firms have recognized the importance of corporate websites as means to establish relationships with potential and current customers (Dou and Krishnamurthy 2007). For example, communicating brand values or providing informational material online helps consumers better understand a product or intangible service offering (Wells, Valacich, and Hess 2011). Yet, firms must move beyond a mere focus on the task-related purposes of their websites and determine how to create positive user experiences (Hassenzahl and Tractinsky 2006). For example, research has shown that consumers react positively to hedonic and emotional service quality aspects when shopping online (Bauer, Falk, and Hammerschmidt 2006). This is especially important for innovative websites, which aim to surprise and delight consumers (Soskin 2010).

In this regard, extant literature discusses whether delight and satisfaction are two distinct constructs (Finn 2012; Kumar and Iyer 2001; Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997; Rust, Zahorik, and Keiningham 1994; Verma 2003). To demonstrate that delight and satisfaction differ from each other in an online context and thus exhibit different effects on consumers’ behavioral intentions, an empirical study in cooperation with a German premium car manufacturer was conducted. In total, 323 Internet users who browsed the car manufacturer’s website took part in this study.

To extend current research on the possible antecedents and effects of delight (Arnold et al. 2005; Barnes, Ponder, and Dugar 2011; Berman 2005; Finn, 2011, 2012), a second study describes the attainment of delight in an online environment and its effects on consumer behavior. Despite its relevance, studies in this context are scarce, though Finn (2005, 2011, 2012) provides an overview of the relevance of highly aggregated website quality components in the context of delight. Because website development demands up-front investments, firms need to understand which specific factors evoke delight or surprise and, thus, how to optimize their websites’ user impact. Without such knowledge, firms cannot predict which attitudes consumers are most likely to develop in response to using the website. Similar studies have considered the influence of website quality factors on satisfaction (Bai, Law, and Wen 2008; Kim and Stoel 2004; Lin 2007), but no study has focused on which factors can help induce delight and surprise. According to the technology acceptance model (TAM), the intention to use information technology systems, including websites (Lederer et al. 2000), depends on their perceived ease of use and usefulness (Bagozzi, Davis, and Warshaw 1992; Davis 1989; Davis, Bagozzi, and Warshaw 1989; Venkatesh and Bala 2008; Venkatesh and Davis 2000).

On the one hand, this study adopts the proposition in the TAM that evoked attitudes and beliefs shape consumer intentions and subsequent behaviors. On the other hand, it modifies the original model in two ways. First, in addition to the traditional understanding of TAM, studies have shown that emotions can be integrated into the TAM and that they are responsible for influencing consumer behavior (Venkatesh 2000). Venkatesh (2000) shows that the emotion computer anxiety helps enhance user acceptance of information technologies. Thus, although the traditional TAM focuses on cognitive beliefs, including emotion and addressing affect both help broaden the model. Second, this study combines online-driven constructs, such as website satisfaction and delight, and offline-focused constructs, such as purchase intentions. These are applied to an empirical study, conducted in cooperation with the same German car manufacturer as in Study 1, of 1,931 Internet users who browsed the car manufacturer’s website. To identify relevant antecedents and consequences of delight online, this research expands on two influence factors identified by TAM and tests three WebQual factors (Loiacono, Watson, and Goodhue 2007) to capture consumer evaluations of websites (usefulness, response time, and entertainment). In addition, the study assesses whether evoked delight and surprise are positively related to the target variable purchase intentions. Because car dealers are prominent sales intermediaries, the car manufacturer’s website mainly plays an informational role to facilitate sales activities rather than acting as a direct retail channel. That is, the goal of the website is to increase purchase intentions among potential customers.

Overall, this research offers a five-fold contribution to extant understanding of delight. First, it shows that website satisfaction and delight are distinct constructs with differing effects on consumer behavior. Second, it offers novel insights by identifying individual website quality factors that firms can manipulate to increase the chances of delightful consumer web experiences. Third, by examining and distinguishing the effects of website quality factors on delight and surprise, this study sheds light on how consumers perceive different website quality factors. Fourth, the positive effect of delight on purchase intentions emphasizes the positive returns on firms’ up-front website investments. Fifth, by including real consumers browsing a car manufacturer’s website, this study describes actual, immediate attitudes and behavioral intentions.

sec.title: Delight Versus Satisfaction
sec.p: The concept of delight originates in emotion literature and first appeared in Plutchik’s (1980) model of primary emotions. Delight is a positive emotion (Morgan and Heise 1988; Plutchik 1980; Russell 1980; Shaver et al. 1987; Storm and Storm 1987) that people experience in response to having their expectations exceeded to an unexpected and surprising degree (Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997). This surprise prompts highly activated positive affect (Watson and Tellegen 1985) and a state of greatly aroused pleasantness (Russell 1980). Furthermore, surprise constitutes a “preemotion” (Lazarus 1991, p. 83), because it initially appears neutral (Meyer, Reisenzein, and Schützwohl 1997; Reisenzein 2000; Schützwohl 1998; Storm and Storm 1987). To initiate a positive or negative reaction, the surprising experience must be followed by a subsequent emotion (e.g., surprise + joy; Ekman and Friesen 1975). Regarding the formation of delight, Oliver, Rust, and Varki (1997) detail that surprising and unexpected experiences trigger arousal, which yields pleasure, which in turn leads to delight. The term surprise is used herein to refer to positive experiences in the context of the research.

Because of its positive effects on customer behavior, delight also implies a desirable source of competitive advantage. Delighted customers display more loyalty, greater likelihood to engage in word of mouth, and higher purchase intentions (Arnold et al. 2005; Barnes, Beauchamp, and Webster 2010; Chitturi, Raghunathan, and Mahajan 2008; Kumar 1996). Satisfaction has long been considered the central marketing goal of firms worldwide. However, its impact on customer loyalty has been questioned (e.g., Deming 1988; Leung and Kwong 2009; Schneider and Bowen 1999) because it does not guarantee consistent repurchase intentions (Jones and Sasser 1995). Although some researchers have questioned the difference between high levels of satisfaction and delight (Finn 2012; Kumar and Iyer 2001; Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997; Rust, Zahorik, and Keiningham 1994; Verma 2003), both constructs actually appear distinct. For example, Berman (2005) notes that delight requires out-of-the-ordinary service or product performances. He also proposes that delightful experiences are more memorable than satisfying experiences and thus are more likely to be retained in consumers’ memories. In addition, Finn (2012) shows that satisfaction and delight exert separate effects on behavioral intentions. These findings demonstrate the difference between satisfaction and delight and thus also emphasize that the extant varied research on satisfaction cannot be applied to delight. Therefore, there is a need for additional research to gain an improved scientific understanding of the antecedents and consequences of delight. Thus, in addition to delight and surprise, this study focuses on website satisfaction to demonstrate the difference between satisfaction and delight in terms of increasing purchase intentions among potential customers in an online environment.

Most research into what stimulates delight has focused on factors related to direct contacts between service employees and customers, such as unexpected and surprising service experiences (Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997) or service staff’s behaviors (Arnold et al. 2005; Verma 2003). Apart from Finn’s (2005, 2011) empirical research into delight and service quality online, research has simply noted the theoretical significance of user delight, without providing empirical support (Ginsburg 2010; Soskin 2010).

sec.title: Website Usage
sec.p: In response to increased pressure to secure competitive positions, many companies work to increase customer retention and to achieve added value in the minds of customers, which in turn might enhance their subjective assessments of the brand, the company’s products and services, and customer loyalty (Rust, Zeithaml, and Lemon 2000). During this same period, the Internet has gained remarkable significance as an advertising and marketing channel. Thus, many organizations have focused on establishing corporate websites to provide informational material and foster their brand image to enhance customer relationships and increase their purchase intentions. Extant research has shown that websites can influence consumer attitudes toward the brand (Argyriou, Kitchen, and Melewar 2006), even, for example, a motor vehicle website (Müller and Chandon 2004). As such, this research investigates how companies can use website factors to influence consumer emotions, attitudes, and intentions.

Because an online presence requires an up-front investment to develop and design a website, companies naturally want to determine how consumers will react, how to motivate consumers to use it, and whether its navigation leads to improved behavioral intentions (e.g., purchase). The TAM helps address these questions by describing people’s use of information technology at work (Davis 1989; Davis, Bagozzi, and Warshaw 1989). Since its introduction, research has extended the TAM to analyze the role of social influence and cognitive instrumental processes (TAM2; Venkatesh and Davis 2000), and to investigate how to enhance employees’ adoption and use of information technology (TAM3; Venkatesh and Bala 2008). According to the original TAM, usage intentions depend on the perceived ease of use and perceived usefulness of an information system (Davis 1989). These two determinants shape both attitudes toward the systems and behavioral intentions to use it. Other studies have confirmed this relationship (Adams, Nelson, and Todd 1992; Keil, Beranek, and Konsynski 1995; Segars and Grover 1993), including in the context of website usage (Lederer et al. 2000).

For this research, the TAM’s fundamental belief-attitude-intention-behavior relationship provides the framework for investigating which factors evoke delight and whether the attainment of delight leads to behavioral intentions. The TAM’s proposed relationship applies to cognitively driven behavior, as described in the theory of reasoned action (Ajzen and Fishbein 1980; Fishbein and Ajzen 1975). The delight literature positions it as separate from and in parallel with the more cognitive satisfaction process (Berman 2005; Finn 2012), which consequently is not in contrast with a reasoned action model. However, the TAM’s focus on two influences may be too narrow to fully reflect the various aspects that shape the perceived quality of a website from a consumer’s point of view, such as the site’s aesthetics or its innovativeness. Therefore, the current study approach includes specific dimensions of WebQual (Loiacono, Watson, and Goodhue 2007), which reveal how consumers’ beliefs toward the website influence delight and surprise. In turn, such delight might translate into behavioral intentions (i.e., purchase intentions).

sec.title: Conceptual Model and Hypotheses
sec.p: The research objectives and theoretical background suggest two conceptual models (see Figures 1 and 2) for the two empirical studies described herein. The purpose of the two models is to differentiate satisfaction from delight and to advance knowledge on the influence of website quality factors and the outcomes of delight in an online environment.

sec.title: Satisfaction
sec.p:
Building on Oliver’s (1997) disconfirmation paradigm as a substantial model of customer satisfaction, research has provided insights into the positive effects of satisfaction on business success factors, such as retention (Bolton 1998) and repeat purchase behavior (Szymanski and Henard 2001). Research has shown similar effects with regard to consumers’ satisfaction with a website (Bai, Law, and Wen 2008; Flavián, Guinalíu, and Gurrea 2006). Website satisfaction represents a user’s attitude toward a website. Therefore, this research views it as an object-based attitude. Thus:
Hypothesis 1: The satisfaction consumers experience when visiting a website positively influences their purchase intentions for the advertised product.

sec.title: Delight
sec.p:
Previous research has demonstrated the positive effect of delight on customer behavior, such as repurchases or word-of-mouth recommendations (Barnes, Beauchamp, and Webster 2010; Chitturi, Raghunathan, and Mahajan 2008; Kumar 1996; Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997). This study considers the effect of delight evoked by a website on purchase intention, which represents an individual act, and thus regards delight as an object-based attitude. Because delight is an intense emotion, it should influence consumers’ purchase intentions (Leeper 1948; Plutchik 1980). Thus:
Hypothesis 2: The delight consumers experience when visiting a website positively influences their purchase intentions for the advertised product.

sec.title: Surprise
sec.p:
Previous emotion literature has categorized perceived surprise as a basic human emotion (Izard 1977; Plutchik 1980). Surprises can be positive or negative, but for this study, surprise refers only to positive examples. When evoked, this form of arousal (Alden, Mukherjee, and Hoyer 2000; Filipowicz 2006) acts to intensify the subsequent affective reaction (Charlesworth 1969; Desai 1939). In the context of delight, surprise is an essential antecedent (Finn 2005; Rust and Oliver 2000; Tsai 2011; Verma 2003). Thus:
Hypothesis 3: The surprise consumers experience when visiting a website positively influences delight.

This research also explores how satisfaction with a website and the feeling of delight differ in terms of their ability to stimulate purchase intentions of products in an online environment. Especially in industries driven by emotions for specific products (e.g., automotive industry), firms are interested in finding novel ways to evoke customer emotions to stimulate their purchase intentions (Edvardsson 2005). Thus, this research investigates how firms can motivate purchase intentions not only during the direct sales phase, but also in the presales phase by means of a delighting website design. Considering that satisfaction and delight are distinct constructs (Berman 2005; Finn 2011, 2012) and that delight is a more intense emotion than satisfaction (Schneider and Bowen 1999), this research hypothesizes the following:
Hypothesis 4: Delight has a stronger effect than website satisfaction on purchase intentions.

sec.title: Website Quality Factors
sec.p: The factor of usefulness describes how well information provided on a website meets users’ demand and also captures the degree to which users can retrieve specific information that reflects their needs (Loiacono, Watson, and Goodhue 2007). According to prior research, users value content-rich websites, which in turn influence their acceptance of and attitudes toward that site (Elliott and Speck 2005; Kwon, Kim, and Lee 2002; Selim 2003; Steenkamp and Geyskens 2006). Similarly, usability is also an important aspect in product design and can evoke negative emotions such as frustration or anger if a design is poorly executed (Khalid and Helander 2006).

Therefore, users might be delighted and surprised if they retrieve information that exceeds their initial expectations about the informational value of a website. Thus:
Hypothesis 5: The perception of usefulness when consumers visit a website positively influences surprise.
Hypothesis 6: The perception of usefulness when consumers visit a website positively influences delight.

Advances in broadband technology have enabled Internet users to surf the web at rapid speeds and to retrieve information online more quickly. Therefore, the response time of websites and its perceived necessity by Internet users has steadily increased. The response time or speed of a website influences users’ attitudes (Galletta et al. 2006; Kim and Stoel 2004), and thus a very low response time might be perceived as unexpected:
Hypothesis 7: The perception of response time when consumers visit a website positively influences surprise.
Hypothesis 8: The perception of response time when consumers visit a website positively influences delight.

The entertainment value of a website is another way to engage consumers. In line with Loiacono, Watson, and Goodhue (2007), a website’s entertainment value pertains to its visual appeal and innovativeness. Visual aspects play an important role in determining consumer attitudes toward a website (Geissler, Zinkhan, and Watson 2001; Tractinsky et al. 2006). Color or beauty determines how users navigate and judge websites (Bonnardel, Piolat, and Le Bigot 2011; Schenkman and Jönsson 2000). As such, visual appeal has the potential to go beyond the normal and directly influence user delight (Ginsburg 2010). Technology has enabled firms to alter the appearance of their websites in innovative and unique ways. Furthermore, globalization has pushed companies to apply novel approaches that differentiate them from competitors. Through innovation, companies can stand out and even enhance their business performance (Hult, Hurley, and Knight 2004). Moreover, innovativeness is often linked to novelty (Andrews and Smith 1996; Nieto and Santamaría 2007; Sethi, Smith, and Park 2001); if a website is perceived as innovative, its inherent novelty and related unexpectedness should also be able to trigger surprise (Izard 1977; Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997; Stanley 2009). Similarly, an innovative website with technologically advanced user features could exceed consumer expectations and consequently evoke delight. Thus:
Hypothesis 9: The perception of entertainment when consumers visit a website positively influences surprise.
Hypothesis 10: The perception of entertainment when consumers visit a website positively influences delight.

sec.title: Surprise
sec.p:
As explained previously, surprise acts as an intensifier of a subsequent affective reaction (Charlesworth 1969; Desai 1939) and is an antecedent of delight (Finn 2005; Rust and Oliver 2000; Tsai 2011; Verma 2003). Thus:
Hypothesis 11: The surprise consumers experience when visiting a website positively influences delight.

sec.title: Delight
sec.p:
Delight positively influences customer behavior (Barnes, Beauchamp, and Webster 2010; Chitturi, Raghunathan, and Mahajan 2008; Kumar 1996; Oliver, Rust, and Varki 1997). Research also shows that customers will consider the longevity of emotions throughout the decision-making process (Loewenstein et al. 2011; Shiv and Huber 2000). Consequently, customers interested in purchasing a car are likely to include the associated emotions in their buying decisions (Pollai, Hoelzl, and Possas 2010). When delight is evoked through consumer perceptions of different website factors, this research hypothesizes the following:
Hypothesis 12: The delight consumers experience when visiting a website positively influences their purchase intentions for the advertised product.

sec.title: Overview
sec.p: Two empirical studies were conducted to test the hypotheses. Study 1 aimed to demonstrate that satisfaction and delight are distinct constructs and, as such, exert separate effects on purchase intentions, which represents a central goal in the car industry. The study also intends to show that surprise is an antecedent of delight (Hypotheses 1–4). Study 2 was designed to show how different perceived factors of website quality affect delight and surprise and how the evoked delight influences consumers’ purchase intentions (Hypotheses 5–12).

sec.title: Data Collection
sec.p: For both studies, a survey approach used an online questionnaire to collect the data; the order of the indicators varied randomly. For consumers who browsed the car manufacturer’s website for at least 1 minute, a pop-up window appeared with some informational text encouraging them to participate in a survey. To take part, they had to click on the pop-up window to indicate that they agreed to be questioned and were then directed to a new website to take the survey. Study 1 entailed a 7-day data collection period and Study 2 a 14-day data collection period. After the data were screened and cleaned to remove respondents who closed the pop-up window before completing the questionnaire, 323 cases (30.6%) remained for Study 1 and 1,931 cases (30.2%) remained for Study 2. Of the respondents in Sample 1, 86% were men with an average age of 38 years. The sample of Study 2 consisted of 81% men with a median age of 36 years. The typical proportion of male users of websites of German car manufacturers averages 87% (PSYMA GROUP AG 2010), so both samples adequately reflect the demographic user features of such websites.

sec.title: Measures
sec.p: Both studies relied on existing, validated scales (see Appendices A and B) and applied 5-point Likert-type scales (for delight and surprise: 1 = never and 5 = always; for all other constructs: 1 = strongly disagree and 5 = strongly agree). In Studies 1 and 2, the measures of the degree of experienced delight and surprise (During this visit to the website, how frequently did you feel each of the following? e.g., surprised) came from Finn (2005). A scale from Baker and Churchill (1977) provided the assessment of purchase intentions (e.g., Would you actively seek out this product in order to purchase it?). Study 1 also adopted Oliver and Bearden’s (1983) 2-item scale to assess consumers’ satisfaction with the website (e.g., I am satisfied with the website).

The analysis of the effects of different website experience factors in Study 2 relied on a reduced form of the WebQual dimensions (Loiacono, Watson, and Goodhue 2007). The original measure consists of 12 dimensions, 7 of which are not suitable for this study. Some were excluded because they are not relevant to the research focus or because they apply mainly to retail websites; conversely, this research is based on a website with only informational, purchase-stimulating purposes. The five remaining dimensions used in this analysis were informational fit to task (e.g., The website adequately meets my information needs), tailored communications (e.g., I can interact with the website in order to get information tailored to my specific needs), response time (e.g., When I use the website there is very little waiting time between my actions and the website’s response), visual appeal (e.g., The website is visually appealing), and innovativeness (e.g., The website is innovative). As Loiacono, Watson, and Goodhue (2007) suggest, informational fit to task and tailored communications form the factor usefulness, and visual appeal and innovativeness make up the factor entertainment. The scales appeared in the questionnaire unmodified, except for the construct of entertainment for which one item was excluded because of low-factor loading. Overall, the WebQual dimensions were selected because this measure focuses on elements that can be easily manipulated by website designers and information technology specialists (Zeithaml, Parasuraman, and Malhotra 2002). This measure was also appropriate because the purpose of this research is to identify the website factors that firms can rework to evoke customer emotions (e.g., delight).

Since the target variable purchase intentions could be influenced by other constructs, the control variable “first visit of the website” was included in the structural model of Study 2. This construct measured whether it was an online user’s first visit to the website.

sec.title: Measurement Model Evaluation
sec.p: The measurement model was assessed by means of a confirmatory factor analysis using AMOS 20 and the robust maximum likelihood procedure. The fit indexes to evaluate model fit included chi-square (χ2), degrees of freedom (df), goodness-of-fit index (GFI), adjusted goodness-of-fit index (AGFI), comparative fit index (CFI), and root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA). To indicate an adequate model fit, GFI and AGFI should be greater than .90, CFI should be greater than .95, and RMSEA should be smaller than .08 (Bentler 1992; Bollen 1989; Gefen, Rigdon, and Straub 2011; Hu and Bentler 1999; MacCallum, Browne, and Sugawara 1996). The measurement model is rejected in a test of exact fit: χ2 = 55.05 (df = 29). The other fit indexes are at levels indicative of close fit: GFI = .968, AGFI = .938, CFI = .981, and RMSEA = .053.

To ensure discriminant and convergent validity of the measurement model, several nonparametric quality criteria must be fulfilled: Factor loadings should be greater than .5 (indicator reliability), composite reliability (CR) should exceed .7 (construct reliability), and the average variance extracted (AVE) should be greater than .5 (convergent validity) and larger than the squared correlation with any other construct (discriminant validity; Anderson and Gerbing 1988; Bagozzi and Yi 1988; Chin 1998; Fornell and Larcker 1981; Hulland 1999). The proposed measurement model meets all these quality criteria and thus exhibits good reliability and validity (Table 1).

caption.p: Study 1: Descriptive Statistics, Composite Reliabilities, Squared Correlations, and AVEs.

fn.p: Note. AVE = average variance extracted; CR = composite reliability; SD = standard deviation.
Values on the main diagonal are AVEs; values below are squared correlations.

sec.title: Structural Model Evaluation and Hypotheses Testing
Structural Model Evaluation
sec.p: The structural model is rejected in a test of exact fit: χ2 = 78.94 (df = 30). The other fit indexes are at levels that can be considered indicative of close fit: GFI = .954, AGFI = .916, CFI = .965, and RMSEA = .071. Thus, the explanatory power of the model appears strong (see Figure 3).

caption.p: Study 1: Results research model. *p < .05; **p < .01, ***p < .001; ns, not significant.

sec.title: Hypotheses Testing
sec.p: Hypothesis 1 must be rejected because satisfaction did not have a significant effect on purchase intentions (β = .11, ns). In accordance with Hypothesis 2, delight had a significant effect on purchase intentions (β = .34, p < .001). Consistent with Hypothesis 3, surprise had a significant influence on delight (β = .70, p < .001). Finally, the analysis of Hypotheses 1 and 2 supports the assumption of Hypothesis 4 that the effect of delight on purchase intentions (β = .34, p < .001) is stronger than the effect of website satisfaction on purchase intentions (β = .11, ns), which was not significant.

sec.title: Measurement Model Evaluation
sec.p: Similar to Study 1, the measurement model of Study 2 was also assessed by conducting a confirmatory factor analysis using AMOS 20 and the maximum likelihood procedure. In doing so, the same fit indexes were applied to evaluate model fit. The measurement model is rejected in a test of exact fit: χ2 = 828.02 (df = 191). The other fit indexes are at levels indicative of close fit: GFI = .962, AGFI = .949, CFI = .980, and RMSEA = .042.

To ensure the measurement model’s validity, the same nonparametric quality criteria as in Study 1 were assessed: Factor loadings (indicator reliability), CR (construct reliability), and the AVE (convergent validity) were below the suggested cutoff values. The AVE was also larger than the squared correlation with any other construct (discriminant validity), which indicates that the model exhibited good reliability and validity (Table 2). Based on a model modification, correlated errors were integrated between the 1st and the 2nd item (r = .392, p < .001) as well as the 2nd and the 5th item (r = −.126, p < .001) of the construct usefulness. Further, there is a correlation between the error terms of the 4th and 5th item (r = .196, p < .001) of the construct entertainment.

caption.p: Study 2: Descriptive Statistics, Composite Reliabilities, Squared Correlations, and AVEs.

fn.p: Note. AVE = average variance extracted; CR = composite reliability; SD = standard deviation.
Values on the main diagonal are AVEs; values below are squared correlations.

sec.title: Structural Model Evaluation and Hypotheses Testing
Structural Model Evaluation
sec.p: To assess the quality of the structural model of Study 2, the evaluation was based on the same fit indexes as in Study 1. The structural model is rejected in a test of exact fit: χ2 = 831.45 (df = 195). The other fit indexes are at levels generally considered indicative of close fit: GFI = .961, AGFI = .950, CFI = .980, and RMSEA = .041 (see Figure 4).

caption.p: Study 2: Results research model. *p < .05. **p < .01. ***p < .001; ns, not significant.

sec.title: Hypotheses Testing
sec.p: As Hypothesis 5 predicted, usefulness had a significant effect on surprise (β = .36, p < .001). In accordance with Hypothesis 6, usefulness also had a significant effect on delight (β = .26, p < .001). Response time was positively related to surprise (β = .06, p < .05), but contrary to the assumption of Hypothesis 8, it did not have a significant effect on delight (β = .00, ns). The data provided support for Hypothesis 9, which predicted a significant influence of entertainment on surprise (β = .14, p < .01). Consistent with Hypothesis 10, entertainment had an effect on delight (β = .25, p < .001). As Hypothesis 11 predicted, surprise exerted a strong and significant effect on delight (β = .52, p < .001). This finding is consistent with the corresponding finding in Study 1, which supports the notion that surprise is an elicitor of delight. Finally, in accordance with Hypothesis 12, delight had a significant effect on purchase intentions (β = .50, p < .001). Table 3 provides an overview of the hypotheses and their structural parameter estimates.

caption.p: Structural Parameter Estimates and Overview of Dimension Effects.

sec.p: The control variable first visit of the website had no significant effect on purchase intentions (β = .03, ns).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The purpose of this research was to demonstrate the ability of delight to influence consumers’ behavioral intentions in an online environment and to extend research on the relevance of website quality factors to the context of delight (Finn 2011). To do so, it relied on the TAM and its assertion that an evoked attitude shapes consumer intentions and guides their subsequent behaviors (Davis 1989; Davis, Bagozzi, and Warshaw 1989).

Study 1 examined the effect of delight on purchase intentions in comparison with the effect of customer satisfaction. The findings show that delight and website satisfaction exhibit different effects in an online environment. This adds to the prevalent understanding that customer satisfaction and delight are distinct constructs (Berman 2005; Finn 2012) and, thus, that extant academic knowledge on satisfaction cannot be applied to delight. Furthermore, delight has a stronger influence than website satisfaction on purchase intentions. Therefore, firms need to realize that they can benefit from creating delightful, rather than merely satisfying, web experiences in terms of consumers’ purchase intentions. This research provides an incentive for firms to consider opportunities for improving their web presence because doing so can have far-reaching implications.

The findings of Study 2 offer novel insights into the role of delight online. In particular, the large data set confirms relationships between three of the WebQual dimensions and delight and surprise. As assumed herein, firms can use aspects related to the perceived usefulness and entertainment value of a website to stimulate surprise and delight and thus enhance behavioral intentions. In this research, usefulness had the strongest effect on both surprise and delight, which highlights its significance as an essential necessity in increasing a website’s probability of delighting consumers. Entertainment value had a stronger effect on delight than on surprise. This corresponds to prior research that shows that users make assessments quickly (Lindgaard et al. 2006). Thus, during the process of forming an affective attitude, they might not consider surprise important. Alternatively, they may form attitudes so quickly that they do not cognitively acknowledge the surprise they experienced along the way.

The response time dimension had only a small effect on surprise and a nonsignificant effect on delight. Because of technological progress, Internet users have had vast experience with websites of differing quality levels, which has enabled them to form strong, subjective website quality standards. Perhaps, the ability to retrieve information quickly has become a standard for basic and acceptable website quality (Kano et al. 1984). That is, consumers now take such attributes for granted and expect firms to provide them. As such, fulfilment of these attributes will not induce more satisfaction or delight; however, consumers are likely to be dissatisfied if these attributes are not provided.

From an academic perspective, this research provides additional insights into the distinctiveness of satisfaction and delight. The findings reveal that in contrast with delight, website satisfaction has no significant influence on purchase intention; thus, the findings demonstrate that the two constructs exert different influences on consumers’ behavioral intentions. The findings also show that surprise is necessary to evoke delight, in line with previous research. For example, Plutchik (1980) proposes that a necessary stimulus for delight to occur is a mixture of the two primary emotions joy and surprise; Oliver, Rust, and Varki (1997) also emphasize the need for unexpected high levels of performance to induce the affect-arousal sequence. However, the proposed need for these delight-enabling factors is not commonly shared in the literature. For example, Kumar, Olshavsky, and King (2001) conduct different studies in which the majority of the respondents did not mention surprise to describe delight, but rather referred to it as a joyful emotion. Only some of the respondents associated joy and surprise with delight. Thus, the authors suggest that delightful consumer experiences can be attained with joy alone. In contrast, other researchers have argued that surprise, or a mixture of joy and surprise is necessary for delight to occur (Finn 2005; Rust and Oliver 2000; Verma 2003). The current research found that surprise has a strong influence on delight. Although this finding does not clarify the overall role of surprise, it indicates that surprise is a strong determinant of delight.

sec.title: Managerial Implications
sec.p: To achieve benefits from their investments in the development and maintenance of their websites, firms should focus on specific website quality factors, such as those outlined in this study, to stimulate surprise, customer delight, and purchase intentions. In particular, firms should focus on ensuring that consumers can use the website to retrieve individual pieces of information that reflect their specific needs to create delightful and surprising web experiences. In this research setting, usefulness exhibited the strongest effect on both surprise and delight, which clearly demonstrates the factor’s significance in increasing the emotional appeal of a website and initiating subsequent behavioral responses from consumers. The entertainment value is another important aspect to evoke these effects. Because implementing technological changes to create elaborate visual and interactive environments can be cost intensive, the positive effect of entertainment on delight should provide an incentive to firms. However, they should also understand that consumers may find excess visual complexity and innovativeness of a site unpleasant (Berlyne 1974; Geissler, Zinkhan, and Watson 2006). Moreover, the usability of a website can have the same effect, perhaps because when firms attempt to impress consumers with their exciting web presence, they tend to overlook the importance of usability. Accordingly, website visitors may perceive a website as delighting not only when it is well designed and innovative, but also when it is easy to understand and use.

In addition to usefulness and entertainment as factors that induce delight and surprise, firms must recognize that response time represents a must-have requirement, even though it does not strongly induce delightful web experiences. Without it, however, consumers are likely to develop negative reactions because the website fails to meet their basic requirements.

The positive link from delight to purchase intentions in both studies indicates that even before a consumer’s direct contact with a product or service, the website can increase his or her likelihood to purchase. Therefore, firms should keep the inherent importance of their websites firmly in mind and invest in improving their quality to create delightful virtual consumer experiences.

sec.title: Limitations and Directions for Further Research
sec.p: The findings presented herein advance understanding of delight, but the results are based solely on data gathered from visitors to the website of one car manufacturer. To extend their generalizability, additional research should examine whether various, diverse online service contexts generate similar emotional responses. In this regard, research should also use different sampling approaches. Despite the large number of consumers who participated in the two online surveys, their willingness to do so might have been affected by their personal interest in the car manufacturer and its products. In addition, respondents could choose whether to participate in the survey or not. Therefore, the gathered data might be affected by self-selection bias. Furthermore, Study 2 eliminated several dimensions of the WebQual scale in order to reflect the study context—that is, a website with only informational, purchase-stimulating purposes. The excluded website quality dimensions could also affect delight in the context of retail websites. Further research should include these and other quality dimensions to develop a more detailed understanding of the factors that contribute to the attainment of delight online. Furthermore, in the context of this research, consumers did not need to complete a transaction on the website. Therefore, to reflect an entire e-service process, research should include factors that consumers may encounter after purchasing online.

This research demonstrates that website quality factors can be used to optimize a websites’ user impact by evoking delightful consumer web experiences. However, it does not address the longevity of the emotion or its lasting impact on behavioral intentions. With regard to the hedonic adaptation theory (Frederick and Loewenstein 1999), further studies are required to analyze whether and, if so, to what extent the affective intensity of delight decreases over time.

Finally, this research focused on advancing knowledge on delight in the context of online environments. Further research could expand on the results and address other potential influencing factors, such as satisfaction with previous purchases and current attitudes toward the brand. Research could also include further behavioral outcomes of delight, such as recommendation intentions.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Extant research on delight has largely neglected its antecedents and consequences in an online environment, despite the contributions of websites to consumer relationships with service providers. The findings of the two studies and their managerial implications clearly point to a strong impact of delight online, which firms can use to ensure delightful web experiences for their customers. Considering the technological advances in broadband and hardware technology and the continually growing access to online information, in many cases, websites have emerged as the first point of contact between potential customers and organizations. In this regard, it can be beneficial to create delighting websites instead of merely satisfying ones in terms of the behavioral intentions of consumers. Therefore, firms should carefully design and maintain their websites to add value, even at the earliest stages of their relationships with customers. This research provides important insights into how they can do so, by creating delight and thus encouraging positive consumer attitudes that lead to long-term consumer relationships, from the very first click.

tr.td: During this visit to the website, how frequently did you feel each of the following?
I am satisfied with the website.
I find the website easy to use.
During this visit to the website, how frequently did you feel each of the following?
Would you like to try this product?
Would you actively seek out this product in order to purchase it?
The information on the website is pretty much what I need to carry out my tasks.
The website adequately meets my information needs.
The website allows me to interact with it to receive tailored information.
The website has interactive features, which help me to accomplish my tasks.
I can interact with the website in order to get information tailored to my specific needs.
The information on the website is effective.
When I use the website there is very little waiting time between my actions and the website’s response.
The website takes long to load.
The website displays visually pleasing design.

fn.p: a = item fixed to set scale.

fn.p: The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
